								Absolute blast. The community is very helpful and friendly.  The crafting system is very, very, in depth. This is true sandbox. You looking for a theme park experience? This is not for you. Quests, carts, tools, buildings, roads, docks, bridges, everything is player built. If you can see it, use it, walk on it, someone took the time and effort to create it. Bad community? absolutly not. those bridges you are crossing, somone took the time to build them so you're journey is unobstucted. That fire lighting up the road... somone built it and cut firewood so you're way is lit.  Sick of all the good sandboxes being PVP? no problem. It offeres both PVP and PVE servers.  Like to group play? No problem. Someone is always looking for a tribe memmber to fatten the ranks.  Like to play solo? No problem. Find a piece of land to call you're own and begin that settlement. So much gameplay I cant possibly mention it all here.                                                               I would like to share a couple stories that I feel express the soul of the game. About two years ago I played this, I was lost. Decided to join a tribe, took a few minutes to find one. I did well we got along. Life took me from gaming for a bit. Logged back in and the tribe had vanished. Picking up my belongings, hungry, thirsty I decided to trail my own path. Eventually I found my piece of land to call home.  Life was ruff. My shovel was worn and my back was sore from carrying so much timber. My old Tribe leader noticed me in chat and sure enugh the tribe was still kiking and had simply moved. I explained that my time and effort was imprtant to me and I would continue my work on my settlement. Several hours later my Tribe leader showed up with my old cart. She had dragged that cart all the way around the world to ensure my shelter would be up before winter. Inside the cart was a good supply of tools and food to keep me going. I never asked, she simply did it.                                                                          My first real multi-story structure was started on a Saturday morning. By Sunday evening I was about to ram Xsyon up somone's a**. that building caused me more grief than the IRS.  I was flustered and agitated. I asked in global chat what was I doing wrong and being that no one was accually there to see my issue it would be difficult to determine. I simply had a melt down in chat LOL. Seriously, I was mad. I was about to log off. Closed my gate and began to log off. I turned around to go into my cabin and there stands a GM. I did not hit any help buttons. I didn't scream for GM help in chat. She simply showed up. She did'nt lecture to me about my attitude or threatened a ban, she simply helped me. After a few seconds of education my tower was complete. The issue was so simple.   Wessendale is now populated by 14 people and thriving. Our land mass is vast and we house many multi-story buildings, and holdings that would impress even a king.                                                                     The game is buy to play. It's umm 30 bucks? No monthly fee. No in-game store or micro payments. What are you waiting for? just get it. Thats about the cost of a bad movie and some popcorn. You will get far more than two hours out of this. Don't show up thinking you will run the Xsyon world in twenty minutes, not going to happen. It's the hardships that make this game what it is. Show up with determination and perseverance. Be steadfast and study. In the end you earned what you created.See you in-game!Wessmyre

Early Access Review
								The short version:Xsyon is a great game and if you're a fan of player made worlds, interesting crafting/building systems, or post-apocalyptic survival games, it's definitely worth checking out.The long version:I started playing Xsyon back in 2011, before the game was available on Steam. The game is early access, but don't let that scare you away - in it's current state, the game offers enough content to keep you busy indefinitely. Early access games have been known to contain game-breaking bugs and unfinished features, but that's not the case with Xsyon, as the features that are in the game work. I have encountered bugs from time to time (as in any game), but I have to say that once reported, they are fixed - fast. I've seen the game's dev come into the game and talk with me personally to fix one. The game's team of moderators (guides) are active in not only helping players out with any issues or even questions about the gameplay, but they also hold events and generally seem interested in what they're doing. There have been many major patches rolling out important new features since I've been playing.There is a skill system in place leading to the gathering, crafting, food and building systems. The crafting system allows you to create a ton of different armors, weapons, and utility gear (carts, tools, etc) from materials gathered in the world. The building system allows you to take crafted and gathered objects and build structures in the game (other players can see and interact with the structures, and you and even let them work with you in building them). The building is extremely interesting and has a large array of pieces available, allowing players to create anything from small tents and huts to immense palaces and castles (I have to admit that I personally spend a LOT of time building with my friends in the game - by the time I finish 1 project I have 5 more ideas that I want to try out). The food system allows players to hunt, fish and grow and forage lots of different things, and cook them to make food - it's easy to do the minimum, but players that really invest themselves in this system can create very powerful food items that can help in every day things. The skill system as a whole works well - it's easy to throw yourself in one skill and master it, but harder to master 2 skills, and so on. Playing solo is possible, but the game is much easier playing as a group, allowing you to focus on your chosen skill(s) without worrying about the others.The game is definitely worth checking out - I know I've spent a lot of time playing it (I only connected my Steam and Xsyon accounts a few months ago, even though I started playing in 2011, and am at over 600 hours on Steam) and will continue to play it for a long time.

								I played this game years ago when it first came out and all you could do was terraform the landscape. It quickly lost my attention. I picked it up when it came out on Steam and outside of the low server population, this is a must have game for those into survival/building games. If you like crafting, gathering supplies, exploring, and building structures you will find plenty to do. You can build roads, terraform the landscape, farm the land, cut down trees, build everything in game, and all of this is visible to other players. Everything in game ages and/or gains xp. That Reverant that killed you an hour ago, stole your clothes and shovel from your corpse and now struts around with those items on him, taunting you to come kill him to get it back.Amazingly this game is ran by a single developer; yet, has more thought and work done to it then most MMO's on the market today. If you are looking for a game where twitchy fingers wins the day, this is not that game. This is a survival game, with what could be an attempt at a Trading simulation game. Although there are many aspects of the game that remain unpolished, it is extremely playable and stable, and simple in many regards.The learning curve is somewhere in between WoW and EVE online. It does not appear to have the same depth as EVE Online, but give this game a full staff of developers and it could easily come close over time. The next UO, probably. The next WoW, possibly. It just would depend which direction it went. Of course, neither matter if the graphics do not keep up.The immediate downfall of the game is that the communications systems in game are horrible and most people are into solo gameplay. A new person joining the game is dropped into the middle of a huge map (literally can take hours to travel from one part to another). The server population is so low that I have only seen other players when I requested to meet them in person and travelled to their location. However, everyone is extremely nice and friendly. If the developer moved in the direction of an EVE economy I think this game would have serious staying power, and be able to expand rapidly. However, if one cannot view at distances items for sale, then one might as well be playing a solo or cooperative game, not an MMO. This game needs some way to allow a greater sense of where you as an individual, as a tribe stand in relation to others.Overall, I recommend this game, with the reservations noted above.

Early Access Review
								First of all, the community in this game is awesome, amazing. By and large it is the most mature, friendly and helpful in-game community I have experienced. There aren't very many people playing but there are enough active tribes that would love to recruit you and you won't have to be isolated unless that is how you want to play it. Pros: The community. The unique and quirky style, which is a post-apocalyptic- zombie- low fantasy - Native American inspired -with brightly colored mutant animals that want to eat you - combo. It is a bloody mental mix but I really, really like it. There is immense variety in crafting. The world is beautiful and pretty huge. You can farm and build mind boggling structures. Fully player-driven world. Development is ongoing with new features coming in occasionally and fixes regularly. Cons: low population. Crafting is somewhat grindy and a clickfest. There isn't really an end-game, you really have to take responsibility to create you own experience because the game is player-driven to the extent where you need to self-motivate 100%.  PVP isn't really a thing, I mean there is the PVP server, but no one actually PVPs because 1) combat system is not very good, 2) there aren't enough players on the PVP server to feel justified in killing those few brave souls who care to show up because then you'd be all alone, and 3) there isn't much reason to PVP... most people play this game to roleplay building their town/ mansion and explore the world. This last one isn't really a con IMO.Over all, quite a few cons - but those pros carry much more weight for me. The unique style and feel of the world along with the chance to be really creative and build up amazing looking communities with some really great people - that is basically what I want from a game and so rarely experience. Not everyone will appreciate Xsyon so research thoroughly before you buy. If you are like me you'll be stuck. I have played for over three years (most of that time I didn't launch through steam so my hours played are misleading) and though I am too busy these days to find much time for games, I keep coming back.

								For fans of sandbox MMOs Xsyon is a must.  This game has A LOT of character and offers a very unique experience than your dime a dozen mainstream MMO.  I played it for a while before it came to steam and for a fan of Ultima Online and SWG there are a lot of familiar mecanics here, namely a skill gain by use system.  Everything you do from walking, swimming, crafting, lumberjacking to foraging has a skill attached to it and the more you do that particular thing, the better you get at it.  So everything you do has meaning.  Like real life Xsyon seeks to create a virtual realm where you can basically learn and improve on whatever you wish.  There is also building and terraforming.  You can claim a plot of land, shape it and start building on it - completely open world, where everyone can see it happening.  Guilds can build veritable towns.  You also have the option to choose either a PVP or PVE server, so those who hate ganking will find a very enjoyable and casual gameplay experience on the PVE server along with a very friendly community.One word of warning though.  If combat is your main thing then you might want to give this game a little more time to develop.  The hunting is also a work in progress since there are no ranged weapons/bows as of yet.  Chasing a squirrel through the woods when it's at a fraction of health just to have it jump in a lake and run off because your stamina got too low to persue it is not my idea of fun.  But if you like building, crafting and resource gathering like I do, you will love this MMO.

Early Access Review
								Xsyon is a post apocalyptic MMORPG.  In Xsyon, you will craft various things to assist in your enjoyment of the game.  That is the overall premise. You spawn in the world with very basic clothing and weapons.  You must then find a settlement or tribe, which is the guild system in Xsyon.  If you're lucky like I was, you'll find a good tribe that will hook you up with all the tools and gear you need to survive.  In just 1 day of play time, I was given a cart, bags, and better armor for my travels from the tribe I joined.  So my experience was handed to me initially.  If you don't get all that stuff, the game can be quite fun as you grind skills to craft better stuff.I think if you aren't given everything, the game is more enjoyable as you feel like a true survivor.  As for the combat, unless you play on a PVP server, there's little point in combat.  Right now, it is pretty terrible.  You get screen lag, bad hit detection and the mobs will usually glitch all over the terrain in front of you as you haplessly run after the little critters in an attempt to slay them.  To do any action in Xsyon, you must first equip the required tool in your "right" hand.  For some reason everyone in the world is right handed.  I found this a chore.  You have to open your inventory, drag the tool to your weapon slot, foregoing your weapon, then do the activity.  If you get attacked, you must then quickly open your inventory and drag your weapon to your right hand.  It's cumbersone and clunky.  As I stated above, the performance is an issue.  Looking at massive structures will cause most people to lag out.  I dropped to 8 fps from 30+ just looking in a certain direction.  This problem is noticed by the dev, and I've spoken to him about it so I know for certain.  He's trying to fix the code for this so it doesn't force the user to process everything in the base even though they aren't in the actual base looking at all those assett's.  So why am I recommending this?  It is a unique game.  I can say Xsyon is a one of a kind experience.  It is grindy as all heck though.  You'r skills, unless you have a high intelligence, will go up at a snail's pace. So this requires you to sit in one spot for hours a day and grind one specific resource to mass produce items to level up one particular skill.  If you enjoy this, then you will enjoy Xsyon.  The survival aspect is moderately difficult.  Once you find out where to find animals, you can quickly find meat and cook it.  Water is everywhere in the center of the map.  Going out further you will have some trouble.  A waterskin solves this problem however.  In fact, I was given a waterskin as my first item when I joined the tribe.  So my experience won't be like the average noob.Stick with the game.  The ONE dev there is, is trying to fix broken features right now, like combat.  You will probably never see things like better performance or seiges on tribal bases because there is alot on his plate right now.  If the dev team was 9-10 people, you probably would.  But this game doesn't make enough money to support that size.  At least the subscription is gone now.A few things I'd like to see added to Xsyon:- Being able to mine just about anywhere.- The ability to build small houses even if you area already in a tribe.  This complaint comes up because the tribe I joined was well established and already had their base.  So, gone is the ability to really terraform and create the world I want to live in as the game tag line suggests.  - Torches to carry around.  - Posts to attach said torches to so you can have some decent light at night.I'd say if you want a truly voxel based terraforming MMO with other players, you should look to 7 days to die, Life is Feudal or Minecraft.  Xsyon was never meant to handle full player buildings all over the map.  If you want to build your own house and cultivate crops, you need to create your own tribe. 								NO MORE SUBSCRIPTION FEES: BUY ONCE PLAY FOREVERXsyon is a open world post apocalypse sandbox set after some unknown event that wipes all traces of technology off the face of the earth. The game is set around Lake Tahoe and use the USGS Geological survey data of the surrounding area between California and Nevada. You have the ability to terraform the terrain to help you build a small shack or a large city. You can’t dig tunnels or go underground.Xsyon Features a fairly good skill system that allows you to craft weapons, tools, armor, clothing, buildings and baskets. You can fish anywhere there is water and cook at a campfire, there is also a recipe system that allows you create food which has buffs.You're able to place totem poles which allow you to control land, protect your containers and prevent players from damaging you(pvp server). This also gives you a place to re spawn.I was a big Star Wars Galaxies player back in the day and this game checks a lot of the SWG boxes, yes i'm aware of the emulator.For city builder/planners this game is a lot of fun, there are some bugs its honestly a very relaxing game to play (on the pve server). The playable area is only about 20-30% of the actual game world map itself. If the population ever grew the game world is ready to expand to about 3-4x the current size once the game leaves prelude(i think ea and prelude are the same thing now).PvP is fun if your able to join an existing tribe, I'm mainly a crafter but i do like PvP, i have a character on both servers. Make sure you get into an existing tribe on the War server if you join that server. (dont cry if you get jumped and lose all your stuff thats the point of the war server).It gets a lot crap because it was created by 1 person, with only some contractors here and there helping out. But with any bugs or flaws its better than most of the junk that is coming out today. People complain about the grind because honestly your NOT supposed to grind your skills to level 100 on day 1. If you join a community of players on the server and help out with building a small city you level your skills the intended way. (sorry generation tumblr) I level upped about half of my basketry skills on my character just making the grass components for our tribes architect. Who in turn was building our starting house. Xsyon is a better RPG than Fallout4 & The Division :DIv'e played this game off and on since the 2011 launch. Common question: Game has been out since 2011 what gives?Xsyon is a MMO, much like EQ, RS, Wurm and WoW; WoW took 4-5 years to create and had the disposal of the Blizzard staff. Xsyon doesn't have the luxury, It was created by 1 person and some contractors off and on that have tried to help. Much like when minecraft was released, features aren't completed and wont be completed until a time only the developer knows.Building is hands down the most solid feature of this game and its one of the most time consuming. PvP does have problems but it is still fun.Feel Free to check my recent games history when your wondering if this game is worth it:http://steamcommunity.com/id/xyberviri/games/This isn't even my main character at this time, ive put in more play time than steam can show because of the other account i use. Then ask your self, Do i own any of those games? 			Xsyon Prelude is a post apocalyptic sandbox survival MMO RPG - let's get started! Enjoy the video? Give it a LIKE! Xsyon centers on the Lake Tahoe region in a post apocalyptic period.		

Some Special ThingsIf you play these kinds of games, you will understand many of the things they have in common, from Crafting gear, to building up your home/settlement/tribe. But here are some things I really enjoy about Xsyon you won't see in most (if any) others like it (so not an exhaustive list - just stuff I really like)...+ Quest Creation - Make a quest... what are you looking for and what are you rewarding someone with for completing it? Add these details to your quest, and anyone can complete it!+ Terrain Reforming - When a settlement is abandoned, the structures left behind can be torn down easily. More importantly, when the supported structures are gone, the terrain (any terraforming done) returns pretty quickly to its natural state! How awesome is that?!+ Skill Up by Doing But Also... - Not only do the skills you use increase as you use them, but at the same time you are doing things (crafting, etc) you are filling an XP bar. When full, you get points to spend on ANY other skills as well. It's a nice combo giving you some options without it being a straight free-for-all.+ Setting - This takes place in post-apocalyptic Lake Tahoe. The "world" is the mountainous area surrounding the lake. Things get more dangerous (and rewarding) the farther you explore away from the lake. Native American influences are heavy here and the combination of that with the apoc setting give this really cool "return to the old world" feel that is really compelling for me.

								New Xsyon player here, and here is what I think of this game in just seven hours.  I will update this review as I continue to work in the game.Simple question: "Should I buy this game?"General answer: if you like sandbox free-to-do-as-you-please types, then yes.  It's worth the investment.  You can tell a lot of effort has been put into this game, though it's fairly underdeveloped.  The developer still seems actively involved in the community, but the community is lacking.  Nice people, just few of them on.  Expect to solo while you learn, and that's totally fine.This game is crafting heavy, but it takes a lot of time (and boring clicking and clicking and clicking) to get what you want done.  I mean a lot of time!  Not even so much that it's a lot of time, but that it's super slow-going, and very little instruction in-game, with a fairly generic tutorial.  To have the best chance to start enjoying this game, I advise you make basket making your primary starting hobby.  This will help you get to the baskets you'll need to start developing resources without spending ten hours figuring out that you need to do this, and five more leveling it by farming grass and making thread and so on.  Once you have baskets, you're golden to start working the land.My advice further:  Safely navigate around the lake.  Find an area off the lake that has trees, rocks, and access to the lake.  Set up a tribe.  Start developing your totem area (aka learning your crafts).  Get to know the ten players in the game at any given time.  Eventually join their tribe just so you have something to build onto.  Or keep developing your own.By doing this, you will be in a safe zone for learning the basics.  You will be near a source of food (fishing), ability to develop tools and masonry, have baskets to store your stuff while you get started, and eventually be strong enough to get going on your own adventure or join up with others on a mmo adventure.Cons:  This game is still clunky.  Poor in-game tools.  Poor explanations.  Poor interface that is arduous and annoying.  Not intuitive at all.  But as you get the hang of it, it starts to make sense and works out.  But it's still clunky as all getout.  I imagine the developer is still trying to get this thing rolling, but it's been in dev for going on ten years.  Don't expect much.  Get it for what it is and play it accordingly.  It's worth that much.  Maybe by 2050, he will have it working as fluidly as minecraft.

								Highly ambitious and promising, I havnt been this excited to see a game grow in a long time. Now is the time to buy, create your settler, and find a place in the game. It's amazing to watch this barren wilderness being settled by a growing number of player tribes, everything from trading centers to small campsites. The game world is already quite large, so I can't wait to see what the full map holds when the game exits early access.Can't recommend it enough. Have some patience during your first few hours, take the time to familiarize yourself with the different skill options and crafting menus, join one of the many tribes who go above and beyond to help new players learn and settle in, the game will suck you in.EDIT: While I am still excited for the possibilities of this game's future, some of the initial enthusiasm has died down. The devs have been worryingly inactive in the steam community and xsyon forums. Exploring further in the game world has also let me see just how much the player base has lost some major players. there are several extremely large tribes that have control over huge areas off land, have built and terraformed massive settlements, and then vanished, leaving behind these ghost settlements. While it could be cool at first to see the "ruins" of a lost tribe, these areas are locking down large plots of land, making them unusable for active players. even more so, many of these old super-tribes were very destructive in the way they gathered resources, meaning there are less forests, valuable junk piles have been used up, and all these resources are just sitting on these old tribes' lands, useless. On the opposite end of the spectrum but equally annoying is all the random "tribes" scattered around that were created by 1 player who played for 1 day then quit. these lands are also unusable for active players, often having not a single thing built on them besides the tribe totem pole.I have read elsewhere that tribes are removed if they are inactive for over 3 months. this needs changing. this is far too generous for a single-person tribe, and is useless to help against the large old tribes, which may have 200+ members gone for a year or more, but 1 person keeps logging in, which means that tribe gets to keep all that land. players should be auto-kicked from their tribe if inactive, so that way the tribe will lose that extra land and be reduced to a size that matches the actual number of active members.

								I bought this game over a month ago and have not regretted making the purchase.  Please note that although my playtime record on steam is low (0.7 hours at the time of writing), it does not give a true reflection as I prefer to use the main Xsyon client - as do many other players.There are a couple of issues that I have noticed that have crept up on the forums.1) Subscription. Yes this game is a subscription based model. I know a lot feel its silly to charge a sub for this game. But actually having written in the official forums about possibilities of being free to play, the developer has actually tried testing out different pay models (including changing the sub fee). It was found that free to play created a destructive element in the game, in that it brought players who were not good for the game. Some of the players resorted to exploits, botted and even caused a lot of tension/drama in global chat by being rude/abusive (hence the reason why the majority talk in tribe chat and not global). The Cash shop idea. Wouldn't be good, Basically you are asking the developer to concentrate on making things for the cash shop rather than developing things for the game or patching bugs etc.2) It's Alpha. Well the developer has already commented on this. Basically it's on PRELUDE. So no, it not Alpha or Beta but the next step beyond that. I'm not paying to test a game. I am paying to play a game that is playable and published. Fact is that a majority of MMO's are never truly "finished" on release, hence why there are patches and expansions.3) Player numbers and community. Steam stats do not reflect true numbers. Majority of players still use the Xsyon client via the website as it was the default thing to do pre - steam. It's also a fact that a majority only speak in tribe chat. In the past a lot of drama was caused in global chat which became really problematic and had to be sorted out by GMs in game. The community overall is very mature and helpful. There are many vets who are happy to answer questions. Do understand though that timezone may affect peak hours for this game. I believe the majority of players are in the US/Canada timezones.Now onto the gameThe game tries to be as realistic as possible i.e. meaning you wont be able to kill bears until you have honed and got your skills really high. I believe people have high expectations from the get go and get disappointed because they cannot do the things they want to from the off. Sorry folks but this game is slower paced and longer longevity type gameplaying. Meaning be prepared to put in some hard work before expecting to be able to tackle some of the high end stuff.1) Crafting and resource gathering. Lot's to craft with many more crafting skills planned for the future.  You will need to either trade or gather resources to be able to craft. Be prepared to spend a lot of time gathering resources so you can grind your craft. Crafting and gathering also have a bonus in that each craft skill has a primary and secondary attributes. The more you use the skill, the more likely that the associated attribues with the skill will raise. For example, doing logging will increase your strength and agility. Making you a better fighter.2) Hunting and combat. Yes you can hunt stuff but you have to start off small i.e rats and chickens. You also need to locate them first before being able to kill them. After you kill critters, you can improve your hunting skills by skinning, gutting, decapitating etc. Don't expect to move up quickly as it will take a while to climb up the hunting ladder. There are also zombies called Revenants. Do not mistake these for players. If they kill you, they take your gear and use it. So for every critter that kills a player, they "grow" and increase in strength.3) Thirst and Hunger. Yes you have to manage these. You can fish, forage or farm for food to eat. For thirst you can drink from rivers or fill and carry a waterpouch with you. There is a balance though as overindulging will give you penalties. Become hungry or thirsty and you don't regenerate health and energy. You can die from prolonged thirst and hunger just like in real life.4) Health, Energy and Encumbrance. All of these can be improved as you keep grinding the associated skills. For instance grinding on a skill that increases your strength will help improve the amount you can carry and therefore your encumbrance levels. Health is self explanatory. When it reaches zero, your dead. Energy is basically like stamina. When you perform actions, it uses stamina. For example you can only sprint when you have more than 50% Energy. Once it reaches 50% or less, then you can no longer sprint, just light jog. When you run out of energy you have to rest or stop your action.Encumbrance levels is your carrying capacity. Basically if you are carrying a lot if items, it will be harder to run and uses more energy doing so. One of the ways to make this less of a problem is by using a cart to transport goods.Death has no real penalties at present.5) Tribes. I was lucky to find a nice tribe. Personally I think it's helpful to get into a tribe early on. You can solo but expect to work a lot more. Tribes give you an advantage in that they can give you tools and food so you do not have to worry about it and can concentrate on your skills. Also having someone to give you advice or answer your questions is nice to have. Also large scale building projects is very demanding and much more easier to complete within a tribe and fun too!Like I said I'm still having fun but it's not a game for everyone. The game requires patience and work before you see any progress  - just like in real life. People who have high expectations of being uber in the least amount of time and effort need not apply!I wish people would try the game and give it a chance before turning a blind eye to it. You never know, you might enjoy yourself.

Early Access Review
								As an older player, one that is tired of the theme park easy button style games out there, Xsyon is a very refreshing change . I would highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a game where you need to put in the effort to get the rewards. Unlike many of the other sandbox survival type games, Xsyon  feels more realistic. for instance...To build your camp, you have all the basic knowledge to survive and make your self safe from roving animals or revenants. To make better fortifications, you need to continue learning which you do by building. Eventually you can make a very strong fortress, or rustic compound of cabins to start surviving in style!To survive, you need to either learn to farm and cook your own foods, or fish and hunt to stay alive. Eating and drinking water are critical to this like in real life. You can also forage for berries and other food plants. Of course things like tools, armor, and weapons wear out, so you can either start trading with other players or learn to make those yourself. The more effort you put into it the better those items will become.I have been playing this for 3+ years and have made tons of friends in game and had steady entertainment all along. Each new improvement the Developer puts in has only made the game better for me.If you are looking for a game with long term play that you can grow in, making your lasting mark on the game world, then this game will be right up your alley. If though, you want it all handed to you, or need to rush to the "end" you may not like it. There is a very helpful community in game that can show you the ropes and give you tips. However, may I suggest that you do the tutorials, setup a homestead, and check it out for yourself. Once you are proficient, maybe then join a bigger tribe to have the opportunity to do even bigger and grander things!I really think you are going to enjoy the experience!

Early Access Review
								I'm really enjoying this game for the reasons that others downvote it for.  I'd always chose a subscribtion based game over a free to play one, as free to play games usually are the greater rip-off if you really want to get into them. Almost all games i know of that are advertised for as being "free" turn out to be pay to win after a while. Here you buy the game, pay the monthly fee (you dont even have to do this if you dont mind the skillcap), and that's it. Keep in mind this is a sandbox, not a theme park. This game is what you make of it and strongly encourages team play. If you like grinding for skills and crafting, you can do it. If you like exploring and hunting, you can do it. It's also totally valid to just fish, farm and cook and never leave your homestead. It's totally up to you.You wont start with all off the games posibillities revealed to you, you have to work on your skills and talents to find out what you REALLY can do. Speaking of skills, what you do is what you get, chopping wood will get you logging skill, preparing meals will raise your cooking, clubbing rats will get your fighting skills up. On top of that you can spend some skillpoints rewarded for active gameplay to speed up the process. That's a brilliant concept to me.About limited character customization... that's just not true. There are so many different armor and cloth pieces you can wear, i dont even dare to guess a number, it's hundreds at least. This game is tagged 'Early Access' not for being new but for being in constant developement. It may not be what you expect from a 'Early Access' game, but this one at least is totally playable and enjoyable with a huge area to explore and countless options for crafting and building on two persistent servers. This isnt vaporware like all those other early access games that never leave alpha or are abandoned by the devs after a year or two.About the graphics: I cant stress how much i hate the korean manga style graphics of all the WoW copy games that are out there. This games graphics may not be state of the art, but at least it's very solid with the animations and environment and get's the job done pretty well.Oh, and no magic! No 300 different buttons for this spell and that buff, attack combo here and there and such nonsense. Buffs/debuffs come from food and environmental conditions. that's it. Very refreshing approach!Speaking of combat, it's non target free for all. Swing your weapon and make sure the stuff you want to hit is where the weapon is moving to. That's how combat is done!Not click a target, then have some keyboard macro spit out your favourite attack combo with fireballs and sparks and flashy things until the target is dead. Bleh...so TLDR, this is a special game for special people. love it or hate it, but for the correct reasons.

Early Access Review
								I've been playing the game for over two years, Xsyon has a lot to offer that others games lack or haven't fleshed out the same systems.The game takes a little getting used to when you first start playing but quickly you'll learn and figure it out. I remember when I first started there was no tutorial and what wiki that players had started was severely lacking for information but the community was very helpful and didn't shoot you down when you did have questions. Today the game has a in-depth wiki and tutorial when you log in to the game. This is very helpful to new players entering the game needing guidance. The game in its current state has a lot to offer with in-depth crafting systems, hunting, farming, and cooking. I'm looking forward to seeing the current round of development proceeding forward and trying it out once it makes it in game (pets, mounts, etc etc) you can find current round development under the game section on the main site to see what is next in line. In game I spend a lot of time on weapon, tool, architecture, and bone crafting. These are the things I enjoy doing most and have put my effort in to be the best at. I really like going out from tribe and hunting, I take pleasure in it and also I need the mats for bonecrafting anyway but I get to explore the server and all the while I get the supplies I need while doing so. I love the sense of adventure the game offers, I'm really looking forward to some mapping skill eventually, as exploring what is out there and seeing what players have built, gives me joy, as it's really amazing some of the things that come out of the player base. It's also neat running around seeing things change over time, whether it be a new tribe, or watching the terrain revert back to how it once was since, we have terrain reversion now.Scavenging is by far the one thing I enjoy most out of the game because you never know what recipes or items you will find and I like mapping out scavenging piles. When I say mapping them out, I'm talking about marking which give recipes more so than another or blades, nails, rivets, and the like. I've spent countless hours just running around the map scavenging junk piles looking for the best materials or recipes I could find. It's sort of like playing the lotto. The farming system is pretty in-depth and I'm looking forward to seeing more and more crop types as development goes on along with more cooking recipes. Cooking alone is by far the best system I have seen in a sandbox MMO, having primary ingredients along with seasonings to boost the buffs you get from the meal your eating is awesome to say the least.Terraforming in Xsyon is unlike any other and very precise if you need to be with it. Changing the landscape is one thing I look for in a sandbox so that I can shape the land to the way I want it to be, if I was so inclined to do so I could have a terrace system on a mountain top with ramps leading to each section. You can really do a lot with it and the architecture that is in the game really fits the look and feel of Xsyon. There are a lot of design options to choose from along with designs you can do with laying everything out. You're not limited by skill alone to make a certain sized house, if you want a massive structure 8 stories high and have the materials and time to do so, then go for it. There are no limits other than the ones you set for yourself.The combat system is one reason I like hunting so much, the variables, and directional user input combat like mount and blade is what draws me to it. I have full control over how combat plays out, yes there are random variables that take place but I can race in and do a charged blow and speed away or circle around a opponent. I'm not sitting in one spot watching text scroll and hitting at a determined speed based on skill, stats, and weapon. I determine the combat based on my interaction and yes stats and all that do come in to play but I could lose a battle with a player or creature by miss steps on how I do the combat on my end.I would recommend this game to anyone, Xsyon is exactly what I want out of a open world sandbox MMO game.

Early Access Review
								Well, this is a game still in development, early access so it says, and done by one man. That, in itself, is pretty impressive. The graphics are pretty good for a true sandbox with full terraforming and piecemeal building construction system as well as trees that are actually removed when chopped. All these are rendered obviously which requires a balance between graphics and game performance. It does a good job on that.The building aspect of the game is very versatile and completely customizable. I have seen rustic cabins, tent villages, stilt village areas over water, tree houses and full on castle like structures as well as mad max looking scrap metal compounds. It allows a great flexibility in customizing your tribe to your liking.Nice scavenging system where it almost feels like a lotto each scavenge trying to find those rare blueprints folks pay good money for to get the rare architect plans. Robust and fairly complex cooking and farming system recently introduced. Good asset protection with gate permissions, storage bin permissions and cart permissions. We recently saw the first unique use specification for buildings, a commissary, that greatly reduces food decay rates when stored in it. This hints at a lot of great options forthcoming.The game has some very addictive qualities in certain areas if that is the type of thing you like. The PvE server, the one mostly populated, has a very welcoming and positive community. Helpful to new players and really isn't a lot of griefing or such on their. The PvP server is left alone in that regard allowing your weapons to deal with griefing although I will say that there is not much of a PvP community currently. This Steam release hopefully will breath life back into that.Is it perfect? No. It functions well, the things it has are decently done, the developer is constantly working to correct bugs and issues brought forth by players and has a lot of very interesting things listed to be upcoming.With a completely player driven in game economy, no cash shop or credits or other 'currency' to buy and use in game, it really is a player driven economy. No NPCs besides animals and revenants, which are essentially zombies of abandoned tribes that, if they kill you, will take your equipped weapons and armor to fill gaps in what they are currently wearing or wielding. You could come back and be killed by your own weapons. The combat isn't my thing, but a lot of the players have told me the key is to learn the system.Cooking actually can end up consuming 12 ingredients to make the top end recipes and can buff various attributes, add to healing rates and other things. Pretty complex in that area. Also, you can starve to death of die of thirst, so planning ahead for such is important. Of course, you can drink from any river or the lake. Foraging for food can be done but provides minimal sustenance and making kabobs is a much better way to go.All and all, a fun and creative game with what could well be a very bright future. I would gladly, and have, recommend this game to folks that are into sandbox games and enjoy building or, like me, hoarding. You can end up with a lot of stuff. Also, when tribes become abandoned and the totems decay away, their goods are open for looting.With a focus on tribe (community) building and a fully player modified landscape and only player driven economy (with no cash shop) it is a refreshing game that can suck you in for hours on end without you noticing.Skills are 'grindy' so to speak, leveled up by utilizing those skills. There is no level system. There are experience points that are earned and can be used to level up skills and are often used to level up the more grind intensive skills or just the ones you may not enjoy doing as much.Currently, I would say the game shows it is in early release and thus I would give it a 75-80 out of 100. Hopefully the changes the developer intends to make can up that a bit.

Early Access Review
								Xsyon Xsyon Xsyon...What can I say to persuade you to play this game. Lets be up front... Xsyon isnt for everyone. This isn't a mainstream game. It's a niche game. A free world, open ended sandbox. Not sandbox themed. You get what you put into the game. There is alot of ambiguity, and alot of hiden mechanics that even the veteran players don't know. The learning curve is steep. If you have ever played any large space-based mmo's before their tutorial systems, you know what a daunting learning curve that is. This is no short-termed end-game. Here is what my personal opinion of the game is:Pros:Open ended, there is no end.In depth crafting system.Sandbox, full customization of tribal areas.Very helpful player base, not alot of drama.PvE or PvP Server option.A VERY willing Developer who listens extremely close to their player base.Big ambitions for future expansions.Cons:Currently a low player populationSteep learning curveHard to solo in the gameSlower developmentWhile there are alot of reviews on the billing of the game, I am not fixated on subscriptions. It costs money to make a video game. Time = money. But to be a part of the metamorphasis of this game has beeen awesome. I have enjoyed this game solo and as a large tribe (guild). It is tough going solo unless you are near a larger tribe or willing to travel. That is what I ENJOYED as one of the challenges. The transparancy of development is a refreshing change and I truly feel the maturity level of the existing players is a welcome change. For those that are looking for the "next best thing", do your research. There are alot of apocalyptic games out there, this I would truly categorize as a survival game against the elements more than zombies, rogue bandits or space pirates. Watch your video clips, check out the wiki. I reccomend you overlook this game if you do not want to commit to a long-term game. If you want to be challenged, explore, and enjoy that liberating walk in the wilderness, then this game is definetly worth a try. There is alot of fixation on billing. Dropping cash on any steam game is a gamble. If you put that money on an impulse you will always have it, yet it just takes up space on your hard drive. Do you actually play those 200 games? I have put my focus on the actual game play. I see it as an investment, and as a player in this game I make damn sure that my investments into the development get heard. It's ultimately up to you. Frankly, I enjoy a polite, helpful global chat over epeen sword swinging egos boxing back and forth over who has the most testosterone. Steep learning curve? So what! That to me is part of the challenge. Experiment, ask questions, discover the game for yourself. You want this on a siver platter? Not going to happen. Solo play? Been there done that. I found spending time on the road to trade took too much of my time, but it was my choice to live in a place over 45 minutes real time walk from the nearest tribe to trade with.Again, this game is not for the elite players. This is a casual game, a challenging game, and one worth getting into if you enjoy something outside of the mainstream survival genre. I look forward to seeing you ingame.

								NOTE: just following the core of the tutorial and generally figure out the UI will take about 2 hours by itself. You may or may not come to a conclusion about it within those 2 hours; I didn't.This review is based on a measly 4 hours of play. My normal "likes" are Fallout 4, 7 Days to Die, Empyrion:  open-world sandbox games with a strong creative/builder component.So I should love this game, right?In a nutshell, it just wasn't fun for me. As they say, "your mileage may vary".  I champion the goal of the game, but the implementation just doesn't work for me.Yes, I read the reviews that cautioned that this game is Grindy^11, but I didn't fully appreciate that. You start with a 20-slot backpack, which is already about 2/3 full with the starter stuff, and which quickly fills. You see you have slots for other containers, but you don't generally get recipes for creating them. You have to (for example) level up your basketcraft by picking about a thousand pieces of grass (I don't think this is an exaggeration), and making grass thread, grass string, grass rope, etc. until you unlock the grass container recipe.I cannot emphasize enough how DULL that is. It sounds acceptable in the abstract, but it is pretty painful.Many other sandbox/builder games, like Empyrion and 7 Days to Die, have skill unlocks and prerequisites to be able to make better things; Xsyon is a whole 'nother plane of existence in that regard.The UI doesn't help in this (or any) regard: you'll regularly need 3-4 panels open at any time to accomplish anything. That grass you're collecting? You can only hold 4 bundles at a time, and you can't for some unimaginable reason transfer it to your backpack, so you have to stop every 4 bundles and craft something with it, which of course requires several panes to be open.I ultimately, uh, sad-quit because a humanoid NPC killed me and took my starting weapon and clothes. The clothes I can replace, after a fashion; the weapon would probably take me dozens of hours to make, or have enough cash to buy.I've been waiting a long time to get into one of these types of games (along with Life is Feudal and a few others on my watchlist); I was willing to take a chance on Xsyon since it was on sale. I regret my purchase.THE GOOD:On the PvE server (Peace), the community seemed friendly and helpful, if not small.The movement controls are pretty standard. The map (there's one for PvE and one for PvP) are huge, but everywhere I went seemed very rugged and mountainous (apparently based on the Lake Tahoe area).Let me add one final note: I can see why some people enjoy this game. Building a simple hut is a major accomplishment, and you feel you've accomplished a lot in doing so; I get that, I really do. But the journey is really, really long and tedious. If you want to follow that long road, and some subset of you folks WILL enjoy it, you have my admiration.
